questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

 

The test used for the detection of ketone bodies (KB) in the given scenario of a 15-year-old boy with type I diabetes mellitus is Rothera's Test.

 

Rothera's Test involves the reaction of acetoacetate with sodium nitroprusside and glycine in an alkaline medium. This reaction forms a purple-colored complex, indicating the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of reducing sugars, such as glucose, in a solution.

 

Option C. Seliwanoff's test is used to differentiate between different types of sugars, particularly distinguishing ketoses from aldoses.

 

Option D. Biuret test The Biuret test is used to detect the presence of proteins in a sample by reacting with peptide bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.

 

In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.

questions.text: A patient came with infective endocarditis. Examination showed gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the likely etiological agent? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus viridans

 

The key points that indicate Streptococcus viridans as the causative agent are:

 

1. The patient has infective endocarditis, which is commonly caused by Streptococcus viridans.

 

 

2. The microscopic examination showed gram-positive cocci arranged in chains, which is a characteristic morphology of Streptococcus viridans.

 

3. The image provided also confirms the presence of gram-positive cocci (violet color) arranged in long chains.

 

4. Among the options, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Enterococcus typically appear as diplococci (in pairs) and not in chains, ruling them out.

 

5. Streptococcus pyogenes is more commonly associated with rheumatic fever endocarditis rather than infective endocarditis.

 

Gram Positive cocci

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pyogenes: This beta-hemolytic streptococcus is a common cause of rheumatic fever and pharyngitis but not typically associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae: This alpha-hemolytic streptococcus appears as gram-positive diplococci (in pairs) and is a common cause of pneumonia but not a typical cause of infective endocarditis.

 

Option D. Enterococcus: These gram-positive cocci also appear in pairs (diplococci) and are not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Streptococcus viridans, an alpha-hemolytic streptococcus found in the normal oral flora, is a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying heart valve abnormalities or prosthetic heart valves. Its characteristic microscopic appearance of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in treatment of the above condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IV digoxin

 

The condition described in the scenario is likely High-Altitude Headache (HAH) and High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), which can occur due to rapid ascent to high altitudes.

 

Digoxin is a medication primarily used for the treatment of heart conditions, such as heart failure and certain irregular heart rhythms like atrial fibrillation therefore, digoxin is not used for the above condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate Descent: This is the most effective treatment for HAPE and other altitude sickness symptoms. Descending to lower altitudes where the air pressure is higher can alleviate symptoms by increasing the available oxygen.

 

Option C. Administration of Oxygen: Providing supplemental oxygen can help alleviate the symptoms of hypoxia experienced at high altitudes, directly addressing the oxygen deficit caused by the thin air.

 

Option D. Tablet Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a diuretic that helps prevent and reduce the symptoms of altitude sickness. It works by acidifying the blood, which stimulates breathing, increasing oxygen intake and helping the body adjust to changes in altitude.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barometric pressure, partial pressure of oxygen and common effects at different altitudes

 

 

Treatment

 

  1. Oxygen supplementation
  2. Move to a lower altitude
  3. Acetazolamide – stimulates respiration and reduced intracranial pressure
  4. Portable hyperbaric bags (E.g., Gamow bag) simulate descent to a lower altitude.

choices.text: Components of MELD (Model for end stage liver disease) scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L).
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy.
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, and INR.
MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation.

questions.text: Which among the following is false? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, and INR

 

Statement C is false. The Child Turcotte Pugh (CTP) score does not include creatinine as a component. Instead, CTP uses the following parameters to assess the severity of liver disease: bilirubin, albumin, INR, ascites, and encephalopathy. This score is traditionally used to evaluate the prognosis in chronic liver disease, primarily cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Components of MELD scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L): This statement is true. The MELD score has been updated to include serum sodium along with creatinine, bilirubin, and INR to improve its accuracy in predicting mortality risk in liver transplant candidates.

 

Option B. Components of CTP score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy: This is accurate and reflects the correct components of the CTP score.

 

Option D. MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation: This is true. The MELD score is widely used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation based on their risk of death from liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MELD-Na components mnemonic “CBI”

 

C - Creatinine

B - Bilirubin

I - INR + Sodium

 

CTP score mnemonic BANANa

 

  • Bilirubin Albumin INR Ascites eNcephalopathy

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

questions.text: Name the material which is used for Lichtenstein mesh repair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polypropylene

 

The material used for Lichtenstein mesh repair is polypropylene, commonly referred to as Prolene mesh. It is a non-absorbable synthetic mesh, meaning it remains in the body permanently to provide ongoing support to the repaired area. The Lichtenstein repair technique is commonly used in hernia surgery to provide a tension-free repair by reinforcing the weakened area with this mesh.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyglycolic acid: This is incorrect because polyglycolic acid is an absorbable suture material and not suitable for long-term reinforcement as required in mesh repair.

 

Option C. Polyacrylamide: This is incorrect because polyacrylamide is not used in surgical mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Polygalactin: This is incorrect as polygalactin (Vicryl) is also an absorbable material used primarily for suturing, not for permanent mesh repair.

 

Extra edge:

 

In intraperitoneal repair, IPOM (Intraperitoneal onlay mesh), the mesh that you use is called a dual mesh or a composite mesh. So it will have proline on one side, it will have a collagen or a Teflon on the other side. So it has two surfaces, one surface facing upwards towards the peritoneum, one surface facing downwards towards the intestines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polypropylene mesh is the material of choice for Lichtenstein mesh repair due to its non-absorbable nature, providing long-term reinforcement for hernia repairs.

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus
Ebstein Barr virus

questions.text: A patient underwent a renal transplant following which he developed an infection that had owl eye inclusions. What is the likely cause of the finding? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus

 

The presence of owl eye inclusions in a patient with a history of immunosuppression (such as following a renal transplant) is highly suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

 

  • Pathology: CMV is a member of the herpesvirus family and is a common cause of infection in immunocompromised individuals. The virus causes the formation of characteristic intranuclear inclusions that resemble owl's eyes.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with fever, fatigue, and signs of organ-specific involvement, such as pneumonitis, hepatitis, or retinitis, depending on the site of infection.
  • Histopathology: The characteristic finding on histopathology is the presence of large cells with basophilic intranuclear inclusions surrounded by a clear halo, giving the appearance of owl's eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex virus: Typically causes vesicular lesions and does not produce owl eye inclusions.

 

Option B. Epstein Barr virus: Associated with infectious mononucleosis and various lymphoproliferative disorders, not typically owl eye inclusions.

 

Option D. HIV: Causes immunosuppression but does not produce characteristic owl eye inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Owl eye inclusions seen in immunocompromised patients, especially post-transplant, are indicative of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

questions.text: A dead body of a baby is brought for autopsy which is alleged to be a case of spontaneous abortion. On autopsy, ossification center of Talus is seen. What is the minimum gestational age of baby? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7 months

 

Explanation:

 

The appearance of the ossification center in the talus occurs at around 7 months of gestation.

 

Key points to remember related to gestational age of 7th month:

 

  • Ossification centre - Talus, S2, and S3: Appear at 7 months of intrauterine age.
  • Age of Viability: 7 months of gestation, the child can have a separate existence from the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossification Centers and Gestational Age

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal obstruction after being hit on the face from the front. On examination, a boggy swelling of the septum is seen on both sides (see picture below), which is fluctuant on palpation with a swab or blunt probe. He should be managed by?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Incision & Drainage

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with nasal obstruction and a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum on both sides after trauma, which indicates a septal hematoma. A septal hematoma is a collection of blood within the septal tissues and requires immediate drainage to prevent complications such as infection, abscess formation, or septal cartilage necrosis. The definitive treatment is incision and drainage to evacuate the collected blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal packing: Nasal packing is not the treatment of choice for a septal hematoma. It is typically used for controlling nasal bleeding (epistaxis).

 

Option C. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be used to prevent secondary infection, they do not address the primary issue of the hematoma and are not the definitive treatment.

 

Option D. Nasal decongestants: Nasal decongestants are used to reduce nasal mucosal swelling and congestion but are not effective in treating a septal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A septal hematoma, characterized by a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum after nasal trauma, should be treated with immediate incision and drainage to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.

questions.text: Match the following eggs to the organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. The Hymenolepis nana egg - The egg is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryopore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere.  The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

2. Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm)

 

Two types of eggs are passed by the worms: (1) fertilized and (2) unfertilized.

 

  1. The fertilized eggs, laid by females, inseminated by mating with a male, are embryonated and develop into the infective eggs (Figs 3A to C. .
  2. The unfertilized eggs, are laid by uninseminated female. These are nonembryonated and cannot become infective

 

Features of roundworm egg

 

 

 

3. The egg of Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) is:

 

Oval or elliptical, measuring 60 μm by 40 mcm.

 

Colorless, not bile stained.

 

Surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.

 

Floats in saturated salt solution.

 

When released by the worm in the intestine, the egg contains an unsegmented ovum.

 

During its passage down the intestine, the ovum develops. When passed in feces, the egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with four or eight blastomeres.

 

There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and the egg shell (Figs A and B).

 

 

4. The eggs of Taenia solium and Tania saginata are indistinguishable.

 

The egg is spherical, measuring 30-40 mcm diameter. lt has a thin hyaline embryonic membrane around it, which soon disappears after release. The inner embryophore is radially striated and is yellow brown due to bile staining. In the center is a fully-developed embryo (oncosphere) with three pairs of hooklets (hexacanth embryo). The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to humans, whereas the eggs of T. solium are infective to pigs and humans too.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with symptoms of bone pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal impairment. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The patient is started on a treatment regimen. Which of the following treatments is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bortezomib

 

Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor that is commonly used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. It works by inhibiting the proteasome, which is essential for protein degradation in cells, leading to the accumulation of proteins that induce cell death, particularly in cancer cells. However, Bortezomib is also an immunosuppressant, and one of its known side effects is an increased risk of reactivating latent infections, including herpes zoster (shingles). Herpes zoster is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which remains dormant in nerve tissue after an initial chickenpox infection. Immunosuppressive therapies can lower the body's immune response, allowing this virus to reactivate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lenalidomide: While lenalidomide is also used in the treatment of multiple myeloma and has immunomodulatory effects, it is less commonly associated with herpes zoster reactivation compared to Bortezomib.

 

Option C. Daratumumab: This monoclonal antibody targets CD38 on myeloma cells and has a different side effect profile, with a lower risk of herpes zoster reactivation.

 

Option D. Melphalan: Melphalan is an alkylating agent used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, but it is less likely than Bortezomib to cause reactivation of herpes zoster.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bortezomib, a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster due to its immunosuppressive properties. This highlights the importance of monitoring patients on such treatments for signs of viral reactivation

questions.text: Diagnose the image seen in a 10-year-old child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herbert pits

 

Herbert pits are depressions seen on the cornea, typically found in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. These pits are formed when the follicles, which are lymphocyte aggregates, present at the limbus (called Herbert follicles) rupture or degenerate, leaving behind characteristic pits. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with trachoma who have chronic eye rubbing due to persistent irritation.

 

Other findings of trachoma are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner Trantas spots: These are white, elevated, gelatinous spots seen at the limbus, usually associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), an allergic condition of the eye. They are composed of eosinophils and epithelial cells and are not associated with depressions on the cornea.

 

 

Other findings of VKC are –

 

 

Giant papillae, also known as the cobblestone appearance

 

 

Ropey discharge (Maxwell-Leon sign)

 

Option C. Pannus: Pannus is the growth of abnormal blood vessels into the cornea, often accompanied by fibrovascular tissue. This condition is typically seen in trachoma but presents as vascularization rather than depressions.

 

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: This refers to a group of genetic disorders that cause the accumulation of abnormal material in the cornea. Corneal dystrophies present with clouding, swelling, or other structural changes in the cornea, not with pits or depressions.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Herbert pits are characteristic depressions found in the cornea due to the rupture of follicles, commonly seen in trachoma.

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen lacerum

 

Explanation:

 

The foramen lacerum is a triangular-shaped foramen located in the skull base. It is largely filled with cartilage in a living individual and serves as a landmark rather than a conduit for significant neurovascular structures (though some smaller emissary veins and nerves might pass through). Importantly, the internal carotid artery courses superiorly to this foramen but doesn't pass through it. The foramen lacerum is bordered by three bones:

 

  • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.

 

The foramen lacerum is covered by a fibrous membrane, which makes it difficult to see and access.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foramen magnum: The foramen magnum is the largest foramen of the skull and is located in its base. Through it pass the medulla oblongata (which becomes the spinal cord as it exits the skull), the vertebral arteries, spinal parts of the accessory nerves, and the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. It is formed entirely by the occipital bone.

 

Option C. Foramen rotundum: The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. Through this foramen, the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (V2) exits the cranial cavity to enter the pterygopalatine fossa. It is formed solely by the sphenoid bone.

 

Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen): The jugular foramen is a large irregular opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This foramen transmits the internal jugular vein and several cranial nerves: the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) nerves. It is formed by two bones:

 

  1. Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  2. Posteromedially: the occipital bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The foramen lacerum's formation by three bones (the petrous part of the temporal bone, greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and basilar part of the occipital bone) makes it unique among the foramina at the base of the skull. Understanding its anatomical context and relations is crucial for interpreting imaging and planning surgeries involving the cranial base.

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

Notice that the disease is present in all 3 generations. It is being transmitted with equal frequency from affected father to his daughters and son. So, it is autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.  The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome

 

Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissue, including the skeleton, cardiovascular system, and eyes.

 

Important features of Marfan syndrome:

 

  • Tall stature with disproportionately long limbs and fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Aortic root dilation, which can lead to aortic aneurysm and dissection
  • Mitral valve prolapses
  • Lens dislocation, which can cause visual impairment or blindness
  • Skeletal abnormalities, such as scoliosis and chest deformities
  • Stretch marks (striae) on the skin that are not related to weight gain or loss
  • Joint hypermobility
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is made based on clinical features and genetic testing. Treatment typically involves management of cardiovascular complications, such as regular monitoring of the aorta and prophylactic aortic surgery, if necessary, as well as management of other symptoms such as lens dislocation and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the hormones A & B giving negative feedback on Hypothalamus – pituitary axis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibin and Testosterone

 

In the diagram, you can see that hormone A is produced by Sertoli cells and hormone B is produced by Leydig cells. In the male reproductive system:

 

Inhibin (A), produced by Sertoli cells within the seminiferous tubules of the testes, specifically inhibits the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary gland.

 

Testosterone (B), produced by Leydig cells, exerts negative feedback on both the hypothalamus to inhibit the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and on the anterior pituitary to decrease the secretion of luteinizing hormone (LH) and FSH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrogen and Progesterone: These are primarily female sex hormones involved in the female reproductive cycle and do not provide negative feedback in the male reproductive axis as represented in the diagram.

 

Option C. Cortisol and Aldosterone: These hormones are involved in the stress response and electrolyte balance, respectively, and are part of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, not the reproductive axis.

 

Option D. Thyroxine and Triiodothyronine: These thyroid hormones exert negative feedback on the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis, not the reproductive axis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin and Testosterone are the hormones produced by Sertoli and Leydig cells, respectively, that provide negative feedback on the hypothalamus-pituitary axis in the male reproductive system.

questions.text: Which fusion exocytosis complex is affected in tetanus?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synaptobrevin

 

Synaptobrevin, also known as VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein), is one of the proteins involved in the SNARE complex, which plays a crucial role in mediating vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release at the synaptic cleft. In tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin specifically targets and cleaves synaptobrevin, preventing the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA and glycine. This leads to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Snap 25: SNAP-25 (synaptosomal-associated protein 25) is another component of the SNARE complex involved in neurotransmitter release. It is not directly targeted by the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Option C. Syntaxin: Syntaxin is a third component of the SNARE complex, and like SNAP-25, it is not the primary target of the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Option D. Synaptophysin: Synaptophysin is a synaptic vesicle membrane protein, but it is not directly involved in the SNARE complex or the process of exocytosis. It is not affected by the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical students should understand that in tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin targets and affects synaptobrevin (VAMP), disrupting the SNARE complex and inhibiting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, leading to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis. This knowledge is important for understanding the pathophysiology of tetanus.

 

The light chain of tetanospasmin cleave the Gln76-Phe77 bond of synaptobrevin which is an integral V-SNARE necessary for vesicle fusion to membranes in CNS and thus by cleaving this SNARE, TeNT has the effect of interfering with exocytosis of neurotransmitters such as γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons causing violent spastic paralysis.

 

Ref- Ananthanarayan and Paniker 10th e/p 265

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pour plate culture

 

Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However, it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it's high sensitivity and specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Screening Tests for UTI:

 

Option B. Griess Nitrite test: This test detects nitrites in the urine, which are generally produced by nitrate-reducing bacteria such as Escherichia coli, a common cause of UTIs. It is a quick and effective screening tool.

 

Option C. Leukocyte esterase test: This test identifies the presence of leukocyte esterase, an enzyme released by white blood cells (leukocytes). A positive result suggests inflammation or infection, common in UTIs.

 

Option D. Wet mount examination: This involves examining a sample of urine under a microscope to detect the presence of pus cells, bacteria, or other elements indicative of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

 

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine.
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

 

Quantitative Culture:

 

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

questions.text: All of the following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in Refeeding Syndrome except: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia

 

Explanation:

 

Refeeding syndrome occurs when nutrients are reintroduced to a severely malnourished patient, leading to metabolic and electrolyte disturbances. The reintroduction of carbohydrates causes an insulin surge, which drives electrolytes into cells, resulting in the following abnormalities:

 

  • Hypokalemia: Potassium is driven into cells, lowering serum levels.
  • Hypophosphatemia: Phosphate is used up in the production of ATP, lowering serum levels.
  • Hypocalcemia: Increased cellular uptake of calcium can lower serum levels.

 

These hypoelectrolyte states are critical to monitor as they can lead to severe complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and respiratory failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A.  Hypokalemia: This is not seen in refeeding syndrome. Instead, refeeding syndrome typically results in hypokalemia due to the intracellular shift of potassium.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Seen due to the cellular uptake of calcium.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: A hallmark of refeeding syndrome, driven by increased cellular utilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Refeeding syndrome is characterized by multiple hypoelectrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypocalcemia, but not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with knee pain following a fall from the stairs. The physical and radiological evaluation revealed injury to the marked structure. Identify the structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tibial tuberosity

 

In this case, the injury is localized to the tibial tuberosity, a prominent bony projection on the anterior aspect of the tibia. The tibial tuberosity serves as the attachment point for the patellar ligament. Injuries to this region, especially in young, active individuals (often seen in adolescents), can be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is an osteochondritis of the tibial tuberosity. This condition is common in children and adolescents undergoing growth spurts and is characterized by knee pain, swelling, and tenderness at the tibial tuberosity following physical activity or trauma, such as a fall from stairs.

 

The patient in this question, a 10-year-old with knee pain after a fall, shows signs consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medial tubercle: The medial tubercle refers to the medial part of the tibial plateau and is not directly related to the symptoms or the location of the injury in this case.

 

Option C. Gerdy's tubercle: Gerdy's tubercle is the insertion site for the iliotibial band on the lateral side of the tibia. The injury in the image and description does not involve Gerdy's tubercle, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Anterior intercondylar area: This area is located between the condyles of the tibia and is the site of cruciate ligament attachments. However, this is not the structure marked or injured in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibial tuberosity is the site of attachment for the patellar ligament, and injuries to this region, particularly in young individuals, can result in conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease, characterized by pain at the site, especially following physical activity or trauma.

choices.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD
Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for severe acute malnutrition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for age less than -3 SD

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is a serious health condition in children that requires urgent attention. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines SAM based on specific criteria, which are indicators of a child's nutritional status and risk of mortality.

 

Criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):

 

  • Weight for height less than -3 SD (Standard Deviations)
  • Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 mm
  • Bilateral Pedal Edema

 

However, Weight for age less than -3 SD is not a criterion for diagnosing severe acute malnutrition. While weight-for-age is a measure used to assess growth and general nutritional status, it does not specifically define SAM. Instead, weight-for-age is more indicative of general undernutrition or stunting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition is defined by weight-for-height less than -3 SD, MUAC < 115 mm, or the presence of bilateral pedal edema, but not by weight-for-age less than -3 SD.

choices.text: Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis
Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast

questions.text: Which of the options below is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor size <4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis

 

Options B, C, and D are contraindications for breast conservative surgery, whereas option A is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery.

 

Breast-conserving surgery, also known as lumpectomy or partial mastectomy, is a suitable option when the primary tumor in the breast is relatively small (typically less than 4 cm). Presence of N1 disease (ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph node metastasis) is not a contra-indicated. However, since LN are already involved, a sentinel lymph biopsy is not needed, and up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast: Breast-conserving surgery aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much of the breast tissue as possible. If the tumor size exceeds the size of the breast, it may not be feasible to perform breast-conserving surgery, as there would be insufficient healthy breast tissue remaining.

 

Option C. Previous chest irradiation: Previous chest irradiation, especially at high doses, can affect the breast tissue's tolerance to additional radiation. It may limit the use of breast-conserving surgery due to concerns about radiation toxicity.

 

Option D. Presence of multiple tumors: Breast-conserving surgery is typically performed for a single primary tumor in the breast. If there are multiple tumors in different areas of the breast, it may not be suitable for breast-conserving surgery, as it may be challenging to achieve clear margins and preserve breast tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Breast conservative surgery involves the removal of the primary breast cancer with adequate normal breast tissue, followed by adjuvant radiotherapy and assessment of regional lymph nodes through a separate axillary incision.

 

Absolute contraindications for breast conservative surgery include pregnancy, persistently positive margins, multicentric lumps, diffuse microcalcification, extensive ductal carcinoma in situ, and inflammatory breast cancer.

 

Relative contraindications include active systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, a large lump-to-breast ratio (>5 cm size lump), known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e., BRCA1, BRCA2), multifocal disease, and prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast.

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? (INICET Nov 2022)

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

 

Explanation:

 

a. Low APGAR score: SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.

 

b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.

 

c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.

 

d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text: Thiazide works on ________ in DCT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Na+ Cl- Cotransporter

 

Explanation:

 

Thiazide diuretics act specifically on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron. They inhibit the sodium-chloride (Na+ Cl-) cotransporter, which is responsible for the reabsorption of sodium and chloride from the lumen of the DCT into the cells. This inhibition leads to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, resulting in diuresis (increased urine production).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+ K+ 2Cl- Cotransporter: This cotransporter is located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, not in the DCT. Therefore, thiazide diuretics do not act on this transporter.

 

Option B. ENaC Channels: Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) are found in the collecting duct (CD), not the DCT. Thiazide diuretics do not affect these channels.

 

Option D. Na+ H+ Antiport: This antiport mechanism is not the target of thiazide diuretics. They do not act on this transport system in the DCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+ Cl- cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for an overactive bladder in a patient with dementia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Tolterodine

 

Tolterodine is an anticholinergic drug that is specifically used for treating symptoms of overactive bladder, such as frequent urination, urgency, and incontinence. It works by inhibiting the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors in the bladder, which reduces bladder contractions and helps manage overactive bladder symptoms.

 

In patients with dementia, particularly Alzheimer's disease, the use of anticholinergic medications like tolterodine can be concerning because they can potentially exacerbate cognitive decline due to their effects on the central nervous system. However, tolterodine remains a common treatment option when managing overactive bladder in such patients, especially when other options are limited.

 

Remember –

 

Most appropriate treatment for an overactive bladder in a patient with dementia:

 

Mirabegron >> Trospium (as it has minimal CNS entry) >> Tolterodine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tiotropium: Tiotropium is an anticholinergic drug used as a long-acting inhalational bronchodilator in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma. It is not used for treating overactive bladder.

 

Option C. Telenzepine: Telenzepine is a selective M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist used in the treatment of peptic ulcers by reducing gastric acid secretion. It is not indicated for the treatment of overactive bladder.

 

Option D. Tropicamide: Tropicamide is an anticholinergic drug used as an eye drop to induce mydriasis (pupil dilation) and cycloplegia for eye examinations. It is not used for overactive bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolterodine is an appropriate treatment for overactive bladder, but caution is needed in dementia patients due to its anticholinergic properties, which can potentially worsen cognitive function. When selecting an anticholinergic drug for these patients, those with minimal CNS penetration, like trospium, would be preferable if available.

choices.text: It is an inherited red blood cell disorder causing intravascular hemolysis
The diagnosis of the disorder is confirmed by sucrose lysis test
Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition
The commonest cause of mortality is cardiac failure

questions.text: Which of the following is a true/correct statement about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition


Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is an acquired, not inherited, clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder that leads to red blood cell destruction (intravascular hemolysis), thrombosis, and bone marrow failure.

 

The gold standard for diagnosing PNH is flow cytometry, which detects the absence of GPI-anchored proteins (CD55 and CD59) on red blood cells, granulocytes, and monocytes.

 

 The absence of these proteins makes cells vulnerable to complement-mediated destruction, characteristic of PNH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is an inherited red blood cell disorder causing intravascular hemolysis: This statement is incorrect because PNH is not inherited but acquired due to a somatic mutation in the PIGA gene in hematopoietic stem cells.

 

Option B. The diagnosis of the disorder is confirmed by sucrose lysis test: The sucrose lysis test is an older screening test for PNH but is not confirmatory. It has largely been replaced by flow cytometry, which is more accurate and specific for detecting the absence of CD55 and CD59.

 

Option D. The commonest cause of mortality is cardiac failure: This statement is incorrect. The most common cause of mortality in PNH is thrombotic complications, especially hepatic vein thrombosis (Budd-Chiari syndrome), not cardiac failure.

 

Educational Objective:


Flow cytometry is the definitive test for diagnosing PNH by demonstrating the absence of CD55 and CD59 on blood cells.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

 

Option B. Globin part of hemoglobin: 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Globin part of myoglobin: 2,3-BPG does not bind to myoglobin. Myoglobin, primarily found in muscle tissue, has a higher affinity for oxygen and does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. Heme part of myoglobin: The heme part of myoglobin binds to oxygen directly; 2,3-BPG does not bind to this site or affect myoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option D. Heme part of hemoglobin: While the heme part of hemoglobin is the site for oxygen binding, 2,3-BPG does not bind here. It binds at a separate site on the globin chains to modulate oxygen affinity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

choices.text: Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.text: Concerning the mechanism of action of various antimicrobial drugs, which of the following statements is FALSE?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

 

Linezolid is an oxazolidinone antibiotic that actually binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, not the 30S subunit. Its mechanism of action involves the inhibition of protein synthesis by preventing the formation of a functional 70S initiation complex, which is essential for bacterial translation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: is indeed known to inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which is critical for RNA synthesis in bacteria.

 

Option C. Aztreonam: is a monobactam antibiotic that inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, thereby inhibiting peptidoglycan synthesis.

 

Option D. Daptomycin: causes depolarization of bacterial cell membranes, leading to the inhibition of all intracellular synthesis, including protein, DNA, and RNA synthesis, and ultimately cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linezolid binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, not the 30S subunit, making the statement that it binds to the 30S subunit and inhibits protein synthesis false. The other drugs mentioned have their mechanisms correctly stated.

questions.text: A child came with malnutrition and follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions. There was a deficiency of Vitamin A and Essential Fatty Acids. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as "toad skin," is a type of dermatosis characterized by hyperkeratotic papules that primarily occur over the extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. This condition is closely associated with nutritional deficiencies, particularly of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids. In severe cases, deficiencies in other vitamins like Vitamin B complex, Vitamin C, and Vitamin E have also been observed to contribute to this condition.

 

The presentation of follicular hyperkeratotic lesions in a malnourished child, along with documented deficiencies of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, strongly points to phrynoderma. Recognizing this characteristic presentation is crucial in diagnosing and treating the condition effectively.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin C and is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, bruising, and petechiae, but it does not typically cause follicular hyperkeratotic lesions. Therefore, this is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Option C. Keratosis pilaris: This is a common, benign condition that presents with rough, small, acne-like bumps, typically on the arms, thighs, cheeks, and buttocks. It is not associated with the nutritional deficiencies described in the question, making it an unlikely diagnosis here.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis (Darier's disease): This is a genetic skin disorder characterized by greasy, warty papules and plaques in seborrheic areas like the scalp, forehead, upper arms, chest, and back. It is not associated with vitamin deficiencies or malnutrition, which makes it an in Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is associated with malnutrition and deficiencies in Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, and it presents with follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions, particularly over the elbows and knees.

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ureterocele

 

Explanation:

 

  • The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign/ cobra head appearance. It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter.
  • It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Horse shoe kidney: Characterized by a "hand-shake" or "flower vase" sign due to the fusion of the kidneys across the midline, typically seen in the lower lumbar region. This appearance does not match the image shown.

 

 

Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Often causes medial deviation of the ureters or a "silent kidney" if severe obstruction occurs. Not relevant to the observed sign.

 

 

Option D. Posterior urethral valve: Affects male infants primarily and involves obstruction within the posterior urethra, leading to bladder and kidney changes. It does not cause the "cobra head" appearance seen here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureterocele should be suspected when an IVP reveals a "cobra head" sign, representing cystic dilation of the distal ureter. This condition can affect urinary drainage and lead to complications, requiring timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: The serosa is an important tissue layer that forms part of the wall of several parts of the gastrointestinal tract. In which of the following parts of the GI tract is the serosa layer absent? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Esophagus

 

The esophagus does not have a serosa layer. Instead, it has an adventitia, a connective tissue layer that binds the esophagus to surrounding structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stomach: The stomach has a serosa layer, which is the outermost layer of the stomach wall. It is part of the visceral peritoneum that covers the stomach.

 

Option C. Small intestine: The small intestine, like most of the GI tract, has a serosa layer. This layer is continuous with the mesentery that helps attach the small intestine to the posterior abdominal wall.

 

Option D. Large intestine: The large intestine also has a serosa layer, which is part of the visceral peritoneum covering the intestine and is involved in forming the mesocolon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The esophagus is unique in the GI tract as it lacks a serosa layer and instead has an adventitia.

questions.text: A healthcare professional nurse was ordered by a doctor to take patient’s blood sample for glucose estimation. She took this patient’s sample at 8 a.m. which of the following is used to inhibit glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium fluoride


When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.
 

Sodium fluoride is the most commonly used glycolysis inhibitor in blood collection tubes for glucose testing.
 

Mechanism: It inhibits the enzyme enolase in the glycolysis pathway, effectively halting glucose breakdown.
 

Often combined with potassium oxalate (an anticoagulant) in a gray-top tube for glucose measurement.

 

Other options:


Option A. Sodium citrate – Anticoagulant used mainly for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, aPTT). It works by binding calcium, not by inhibiting glycolysis.
 

Option B. Potassium oxalate – Anticoagulant that binds calcium, but does not stop glycolysis on its own. It’s used in combination with sodium fluoride in gray-top tubes.
 

Option D. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) – Anticoagulant used for hematology tests (CBC, ESR). It binds calcium but doesn’t prevent glycolysis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

 

When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows highest concentration in the serum? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ig-G

 

IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the serum. It plays a crucial role in the body's immune response by neutralizing pathogens, opsonizing for phagocytosis, and activating the complement system. IgG is also the only immunoglobulin that can cross the placenta, providing passive immunity to the fetus.

 

Immunoglobulins concentration in the serum are as follow -

 

Ig-G > Ig-A > Ig-M > Ig-D > Ig-E

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ig-M: Incorrect. While IgM is the first antibody to respond to an infection, it is not the most abundant in the serum.

 

Option B. Ig-A: Incorrect. IgA is present in mucosal areas and secretions, but not in the highest concentration in the serum.

 

Option C. Ig-E: Incorrect. IgE is the least abundant in the serum and is primarily involved in allergic responses.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the instrument:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maddox rod

 

The above instrument is a Maddox rod.

 

A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.

 

Maddox Rod Test

 

Patient is asked to fix on a point light in the centre of Maddox tangent scale at a distance of 6 metres. A Maddox rod (which consists of many glass rods of red colour set together in a metallic disc) is placed in front of one eye with axis of the rod parallel to the axis of deviation.

 

 

 

Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria in degrees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maddox wing: An instrument used to measure the horizontal and vertical deviations at near using a different mechanism involving a scale and moving wings.

 

Option B. Maddox glass: This term is not commonly used; it might refer to the Maddox rod or Maddox wing.

 

Option D. Phoropter: An instrument used in refraction testing to determine eyeglass prescriptions, consisting of multiple lenses that can be rotated into place to assess visual acuity and lens power.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maddox rod is an instrument consisting of parallel cylindrical lenses used to convert a point light source into a line image, aiding in the diagnosis of horizontal, vertical, and cyclo deviations in ocular alignment.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushes to OPD today with complaints of upwards rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

The patient is experiencing oculogyric crisis, which is an acute dystonic reaction caused by antipsychotic medications. This is an extrapyramidal side effect that involves sustained, involuntary upward deviation of the eyes.

 

This is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties. It's commonly used as the first-line treatment for acute dystonic reactions, including oculogyric crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lorazepam: Useful for generalized dystonia or akathisia but not the first line for acute oculogyric crisis.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Another antipsychotic, it wouldn't directly treat the acute dystonic reaction.

 

Option D. Stop antipsychotic: While it might be necessary to review and adjust the antipsychotic regimen if a patient is having side effects, simply stopping the antipsychotic won't provide immediate relief from an acute dystonic reaction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect, is characterized by spasm of muscles in any part of the body, e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis. It is seen in about 10% of patients on antipsychotics. Risk factors include young males, those who are antipsychotic naive and high potency antipsychotics. It usually occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic medication. They can be distressing but are reversible. Anticholinergic agents like promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and the ultrasound image provided suggest the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys. Over time, these cysts can enlarge and decrease the functioning of the kidneys, leading to kidney failure.
  • Besides renal symptoms, patients with ADPKD can have other complications, such as cerebral aneurysms (which can rupture leading to strokes), liver cysts, and cardiac valvular diseases.
  • The combination of multiple episodes of hematuria, hypertension, familial history, and the ultrasound findings make this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. It originates from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It may present with hematuria, pain in the flank or loin area, and a palpable abdominal mass. However, the familial context, with the brother's early death from a stroke, doesn't typically fit with the presentation of RCC. RCC occurs in an elderly age group.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the kidney: Tuberculosis (TB) can affect the kidneys, usually as a secondary site from pulmonary TB. This can lead to a chronic inflammatory response. Kidney TB might present with sterile pyuria (white blood cells in urine without bacterial growth), hematuria, and even systemic symptoms of TB like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinical scenario provided doesn't specifically lean toward this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): ARPKD is another inherited form of polycystic kidney disease. However, it's different from ADPKD in that it presents much earlier, usually in childhood or infancy. Symptoms in ARPKD are typically severe and can include kidney failure and liver problems at a young age.

 

  • Given the combination of clinical symptoms, family history, and ultrasound findings, the most probable diagnosis in this scenario is option B, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the OPD with complaints of redness and discharge from both the eyes, raising a suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum. What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlamydia

 

Explanation : 


Chlamydia is the most common bacterial cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries.


Ophthalmia neonatorum is a type of conjunctivitis seen in the neonatal period,  presenting  5-14 days after birth with red eyes and discharge. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery. Requires antibiotic treatment.

 


Other Options:

 

Option B. Gonorrhea: Severe, purulent conjunctivitis presenting 2-5 days after birth. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery, and it correlates with severe complications such as corneal ulceration and perforation, which can potentially result in permanent blindness. Requires Urgent antibiotic treatment.

 

Option C. Chemical conjunctivitis : occurs within 24 hrs , Caused by 1% AgNO3 Crede's method used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum. Presents with mild inflammation, redness, and tearing, and usually resolves on its own.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Less common cause, presenting with mild to moderate redness and discharge. Treated with topical antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 
 

 

(REF: Matejcek A, Goldman RD. Treatment and prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum. Can Fam Physician. 2013 Nov;59(11):1187-90. PMID: 24235191; PMCID: PMC3828094.)

questions.text: Drug resistance is most seen with which STI? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhoea

 

Explanation:

 

  • Gonorrhoea, caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, is known for developing significant resistance to multiple antibiotics.
  • Over the years, Neisseria gonorrhoeae has shown resistance to several classes of antibiotics, including penicillin, tetracycline, and fluoroquinolones.
  • More recently, there has been an increasing number of reports of resistance to cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone, which is currently the first-line treatment for Gonorrhoea.
  • The development of drug resistance in Gonorrhoea is largely due to the bacterium's ability to acquire resistance genes through horizontal gene transfer and spontaneous mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown the same level of widespread antibiotic resistance as gonorrhoea. It is typically treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is relatively rare and has not shown significant issues with antibiotic resistance. It is usually treated with azithromycin, doxycycline, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is typically treated with penicillin. Although there have been some cases of resistance to macrolides like azithromycin, penicillin remains highly effective, and there is no widespread resistance to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gonorrhoea is the STI most commonly associated with significant and increasing antibiotic resistance, posing a major challenge to treatment and control efforts worldwide.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in Iron overdose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BAL

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite), also known as Dimercaprol, is contraindicated in cases of iron overdose. This is because BAL forms toxic complexes with iron, which can worsen the patient’s condition. BAL is typically used as a chelating agent for heavy metals like arsenic, mercury (inorganic), and lead, but it is specifically contraindicated in iron, cadmium, selenium, and organic mercury poisoning due to the risk of severe toxicity.

 

The correct treatment for iron overdose is Desferrioxamine, which specifically binds to iron, forming a stable complex that is then excreted from the body. Desferrioxamine is the treatment of choice in acute iron poisoning due to its specific chelation properties for iron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desferrioxamine: This is the correct treatment for iron overdose as it binds iron effectively and facilitates its excretion. It is not contraindicated; rather, it is the primary treatment option.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): EDTA is not commonly used for iron overdose, as its primary use is in chelating lead and other heavy metals. While it is not the preferred treatment for iron poisoning, it is not specifically contraindicated as BAL is.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because Desferrioxamine is actually the treatment of choice for iron overdose, and EDTA can be used in some cases if Desferrioxamine is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAL is contraindicated in iron overdose due to its potential to form harmful complexes, making Desferrioxamine the preferred treatment in such cases.

choices.text: Block sodium channels
Block potassium channels
Block calcium channels
Block chloride channels

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Block sodium channels

 

  • Mechanism: Local anesthetics primarily act by blocking the sodium channels bound to the membrane of the nerve, thus inhibiting sodium influx into the nerve and avoiding depolarization of the nerve.
  • States of Sodium Channels: The voltage-gated sodium channels exist in three states:
    • Resting (non-conducting)
    • Open (conducting)
    • Inactivated (non-conducting)
  • Affinity: Local anesthetics have maximum affinity for the sodium channels in the inactivated state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Block potassium channels:

Blocking potassium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Potassium channels are more involved in the repolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Option C. Block calcium channels:

Blocking calcium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Calcium channels are more involved in neurotransmitter release at synapses.

 

Option D. Block chloride channels:

Blocking chloride channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Chloride channels are typically associated with inhibitory neurotransmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Standard deviation

 

  • The formula given represents the standard deviation, which measures the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values.
  • It is the square root of the variance, where the variance is the average of the squared differences from the mean.
  • Standard deviation: This is the deviation of each value from the standard value (mean). It provides insight into the spread of the data points around the mean.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance = (Standard deviation)2. It represents the average of the squared deviations from the mean.

 

Option C. Mean is obtained as the sum of all values divided by the number of values. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Standard deviation is the deviation of each value from the standard value [Mean].

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Saline infusion sonography

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • This is an image of a Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • An HSG is used to
    • Delineate uterine anomalies.
    • Endometrial cavity lesions like polyps, adhesions
    • Tubal patency in infertility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopy: Hysteroscopy appears like this image. Using fluid media to distend the uterine cavity, a hysteroscope can visualize the inside of the uterine cavity.

 

 

Option B. Saline infusion sonography: Saline infusion sonography: This is an ultrasound-based investigation, wherein saline is injected in the uterine cavity and this helps detect intra-uterine space occupying lesions and appears like this:

 

 

Option D. Transvaginal ultrasound: This appears like this:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is an X-ray procedure used to delineate uterine anomalies, identify endometrial cavity lesions, and assess tubal patency in cases of infertility.

 

Ref: Page no 588, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition
